"Why don't you take me?"

'Woody Grant' (Bruce Dern) is an old unhappy and rather empty man. He doesn't have much, his entire family see him as a reliability and joke - and his friends no better. So when the opportunity comes that he may have won $1 million dollars - he is adamant its real and he's going to get. Even when he's told time and time again its a scam, it's something he wants/must believe.

At the start of the film it paints him as a stubborn drunk - a man that isn't a particularly good dad or husband. But as things go on and 'David Grant' (Will Forte) begins to really get to know his dad, we learn this guy has had a hard life. And that's what the film is about a man looking for something to shout about and to feel good. All he wants is a truck and an air compressor. He was in the Korean war, possibly forced into his marriage and forever pleasing others while they screw him over. Granted not all this is shown outright as most is in the past but its clear from the actions of his family - loving wife despite her mean disposition.

Much like 'Inside Llewyn Davis' this is a film about a real person in a crappy life (granted in a different form). It's a simple story at heart but with a complex edge to it. Partly thanks to a stunningly quiet and thoughtful performance from 'Dern' and the wonderful original script. Both a beautiful film set in black and White an ugly one thanks to desolate towns that look ready for a tumbleweed to roll through. It has the perfect balance that removing the colour helps as well as putting more emphasis on Woody as a persona and his state of mind. 

Not only is it poignant and nice to look at its down right hilarious. 'June Squibb' who plays 'Kate', Woody's is on fine form with nearly every word out of her mouth getting a laugh. She delivers things with a quick blunt way elevated by the tone of her voice. Not only her but Woody himself, his friends the two creepy nephews. It's largely surprising how funny this film is and its not as if there are large gaps where it takes a break. The best thing is how its able to balance all its plates at once, and with such success. There are moments of pure shock, poignant and hilarity in one.

'The Descendants' was a great film and I doubted 'Alexander Payne' could better that effort but he has and by some distance. A thoughtful, sad, hilarious and happy film that has joined the huge list of mesmerizing films of 2013. Its cinematography, its cast the script everything is carefully selected and perfectly so. I expected to like it but not love it, not just one of the year but it'll be one to add to my all time greats.
Woody Grant, a perfectly portrayed old man by Bruce Dern, a masterpiece I would say. you wouldn't love their mother till the moment when she says: "you can all go fuck yourselves!"

If he's not already there yet, there's no doubt that Alexander Payne is a director who is fast becoming a name that's synonymous with quality. I've yet to see his 1996 debut "Citizen Ruth" but from "Election" in 1999 to the "The Descendants" in 2012, Payne has delivered a consistency that few directors can match. With every film, he just gets better and better and "Nebraska" is no exception.

After receiving a letter from the lottery sweepstakes, elderly Montana resident Woody Grant (Bruce Dern) is convinced he's won $1 million and decides to travel to Nebraska to collect his prize. His son David (Will Forte)  realises that his fathers growing senility has gotten the better of him but decides to accompany him on the journey to look after him. As they make several stops along the way, David learns more about his father's distant past and how it's shaped the person he is now.

After tackling the road-movie in "About Schmidt" and "Sideways" Payne successfully returns to that sub-genre. Like those aforementioned films he, once again, astutely focuses on the interaction between odd and eccentric individuals who are struggling to come to terms with how their life and relationships have worked out. The beauty of Payne's work is his palpable sense of realism and his consistent ability to capture believable character's in all their frailty and vulnerability and "Nebraska" is no different. In fact, it's arguably his finest work yet.

Working from a cleverly nuanced script by Bob Nelson, Payne's casting choices are what really stand out here. A lot has been said about the Oscar nominated performance of Bruce Dern and I can only add that the plaudits and superlatives this veteran actor has received are all very well deserved. Dern is simply marvellous as the cantankerous old-timer Woody, who's stubbornness and determination drives the narrative. That being said, as good as Dern is, he's not the only one on form here. As his patient and good-natured son, Will Forte delivers solid support and another veteran actor in Stacy Keach brings a reminder of his outstanding qualities and begs the question as to why his talents are not utilised more these days. Added this already fine line-up is the marvellous (and also Oscar nominated) June Squibb, as Woody's pugnacious and passionately pragmatic wife. With Jennifer Lawrence already gathering awards for her performance in "American Hustle" and Lupita N'yongo seemingly the viewers favourite for her performance in "12 Years A Slave", I'm very surprised at how little Squibb's work has been mentioned. I've made my mind up that this unsung actress deserves to go home with the coveted golden baldy. She really is that good. 

Primarily, though, this a father/son relationship tale played against the backdrop of a satirical depiction of Americana and it's beautifully touched upon. For a film that has a seemingly sombre and melancholic appearance, it's actually a bittersweet and often hilarious examination of family dynamics, memories and the passing of time which is reflected wonderfully in Payne's decision to shoot in black & white. It's a very wise move and cinematographer Phedon Papamichael's desaturated look not only reflects ageing memories but also the character and mindset of Woody himself, with his outlook and opinion on life consisting of few grey areas.

Payne has crafted a very rich and nuanced character study here, that's not only one of his finest moments but contains some of the best work by everyone involved and is rightly regarded as one the years best films.

Mark Walker

A brilliant and moving picture- the acting, the cinematography, and most of all, the flawless script worked together. Alexander Payne is admirable because he puts the STORY as the main dish in his films. He doesn't strive to impress; instead, he tells a story and, as a writer and ardent moviegoer myself, that's what matters and he earns my respect for that. If I were an Oscar voter, I'll vote for this film as my Best Picture.

An elderly man with tons of determination. Woody Grant, is a senior citizen who's seen the joyous times of his life pass by as he appears to be quietly withering away in the town of Billings, Montana. As of right now, he doesn't have much going for him, and he probably needs something to do just to give him something to do. At home, he has a wife, but she's not exactly the most calm person in the world and she has a mouth that would put even the most foul-mouthed sailors to shame with her raw takes on people (which are hilarious), life and an assortment of other things. So with that being the way that his daily life has turned out, the old man finds out that he may have struck it rich when he gets a letter saying that he's won a million dollars. This revelation has opened his eyes and is bringing him a large amount of joy that he hasn't experienced in seemingly forever, but he just has to find a way to get to Lincoln, Nebraska so he can get his hands on it. Since he doesn't have a car or any money to catch a plane, train or bus, getting there is going to be difficult.



While he's found himself in an interesting predicament, there's a younger man who lives in the same town with the Grant family blood running through his veins. His name is David, and he's one of the two sons that Woody had with his wife Kate. He has his own life, and it contains a few potentially life changing dilemmas that he has to deal with on his own. He loves his father, but he's probably the last person that wants to take on the responsibilities that Woody is offering at that particular time.That's mainly due to the difficulties of his personal life, but it may also have something to do with the way he and his father view the world. Woody is an idealist who's full of hope due to this winning ticket that he has, while David is more of a realist who simply tries to see everything for what it is. So, of course they butt heads a bit when it comes to the winning ticket that Woody currently has in his possession. David's cynical and honest view on life and the ticket doesn't sway Woody from moving on with his goal, and neither does anything else. All of the family members want him to just let it go, but Woody is determined to get what's rightfully his with or without their support. David senses his father's dedication to getting his one million dollar prize, and with the hopes of satisfying his desire, he reluctantly agrees to drive his pops to Nebraska to settle this once and for all.



The casting of Bruce Dern is very good I see why Oscar nominations were due for this film, including Will Forte, director Alexander Payne, scriptwriter Bob Nelson, cinematographer Phedon Papamichael and composer Bob Orton. The scenery of the Midwest becomes part of this family as though they have always been there in each straight line of the road. Music eases into the scenes and becomes one with everyone present. This is what America is about. People, places, and trying to blend the past with what is current, as in an auto body shop, once owned by someone Woody knew. Now, the mechanics speak Spanish and they have no idea who Woody is talking about. Hand-in-hand with the past and then hand-in-hand with the future, life goes on. I believe Nebraska deserves it's high praise for its modest approach to the father/son dynamic and its quietly moving sensibility.

Nebraska, as directed by Alexander Payne, is an incredibly unidealized look at life in the rural Midwest. While the movie's central father/son road trip starts in Montana and spends most of the time in small-town Nebraska, the locations will feel just like home to many Midwesterners. From its rustic dive bars to its weathered citizens, everything in Nebraska feels entirely authentic. Even though the movie shuffles along as slowly as its elderly protagonist, Nebraska is still a simultaneously humorous and exasperating commentary on familial relationships and a population that time forgot.

Should be used in film school as an example of carefully thought out casting, atmosphere and story telling. This film is uncategorizable. It's not a drama. It's not a comedy. It;s not even a dramedy. It is unto itself a tale of parents and children and extended family and the value of hope even when there seems to be none. Bruce Dern once again earned his laurels, underplaying a role that could have easily been a loud and screeching mess. Supporting cast, too, was perfect. in that I felt  empathy for every single one of the supporting characters, even in their ugliest of moments. The truth to me of a great film is when even the most contemptuous of characters reveals at some moment, large or small, their humanity.

You can never go home again. What's done is done, the past is the past. These are all things we tell ourselves as we deal with something that absolutely sucks, getting old. It's even tougher to watch your grandparents and parents get older. Of course you don't want to see them go but sometime we find ourselves being selfish, seeing them reminds us that will be us someday. And as painful as letting go of the past is, I wouldn't change the experience of it for anything. All my regrets and failures are as much a part of who I am as the successes and triumphs. This is what Alexander Payne movie do, they touch you personally and make think. They make you feel, even if the exact subject isn't something you've gone thru personally, you can relate it something you have. Nebraska is Payne's best film so far and that is saying a lot considering his track record. Bruce Dern firmly belongs in best actor category this year and if not for such stiff competition, Will Forte would be there. But June Squib was by far my favorite part of this movie. As the the stern matriarch of the family, she has some of the best lines of the year not to mention the most memorable cemetery scene I can ever remember seeing. Probably the scene that got her the nomination. Touching, funny and heartbreaking, Nebraska is flat out great story telling.

Sparse and bittersweet, this is an exceptional film from Alexander Payne. The film's style could almost be called American Gothic, but it is filled with innocent and potent incites into a man's life as viewed through the eyes of his middle-aged son. Will Forte delivers a striking performance.

Shot in black and white, this is the story of an old man named Woody Grant (Bruce Dern) who has the conviction that he won one million dollars based on a sweep stakes letter he receives in the mail and is intent on traveling to Lincoln, Nebraska to collect his winnings. His family realizes the letter is a scam to entice the recipient to order magazines but regardless, his son David (Will Forte) embarks on a road trip with his father that will become very memorable. Most critics rave about this film and I totally agree with Dave Calhoun's (Time Out) comment: ""An intimate road movie about one family that also lingers on the landscapes and fabric of an old-time, dying vision of the American Midwest". In a nutshell that is the essence of this film! I found it depressing, making me think about the inevitability of old age and the hopelessness and boredom found in the town where the family resides. Oh God I could not live there! I am thankful to live in a city that thrills, delights, and captivates me. Never a dull moment in Los Angeles but Billings Montana, no can do. Will it win best picture of the year? Not a chance in my personal opinion. Solid acting by the cast members, the vast majority are senior citizens and I think director Payne did a great job of evoking feelings of nostalgia, sadness, despair and a little triumph at the end. Recommended..

It's interesting to think that there is actually someone who is eager to walk "to" Nebraska. Well, the occasions in which I'm not watching an unhealthy amount of films or listening to an unhealthy amount of music are often occupied by healthy walking, so maybe I'd be willing to migrate to the Midwest, just to get out of the house. It certainly helps if there's a $1 million sweepstakes win waiting for me... and if Lincoln, Nebraska, was recently named the "Happiest & Healthiest" city in America by Gallup-Healthways. Yeah, I reckon the city is pretty happy, but the people living there, not so much. Okay, I guess Nebraska is alright, it's just that there's not much to do there, which makes it fitting that Alexander Payne is making this film about Nebraska, seeing as how not much goes on in his films. No, I like most all of Payne's films pretty well, it's just that a lot of them run together, and I suppose that especially goes for this, which is "About Schmidt 2", complete with a plot about family dysfunction and old people problems, only this time, the color palette is in black-and-white. Man, that sounds about as exciting as, well, Nebraska, but relax, people, because this film about walking is worth sitting through, despite its flaws.

Being that this is an Alexander Payne film with a minimalist plot that is somehow crafted into a two-hour-long final product, it should come as no surprise that this film is slow, even in atmospheric momentum, taking a steady and dryly quiet approach to limp subject matter whose scripted interpretation has enough snap to keep things from getting too slow, yet can't completely make up for the bland spells that ensue when material for Payne to draw upon with his thoughtfulness lapses. Make no mistake, material lapses often, as limpness plagues both Payne's directorial performance and Bob Nelson's writing performance, dragging things out with more than a few aimless sessions of dialogue, much of which is more filler than consequential, just like Payne's other films. Really, with all of my rambling on and on about how this is a formulaic Alexander Payne film, its being so familiar is a big problem, for although Payne's formula still has enough juice in it to subtly compel the patient, too little is unique about this conventional Payne project, whose familiarity would be easier to forgive if the tropes didn't include the aforementioned questionable pacing, as well as some questionable characterization. Characterization is also classic Al Payne, with intentional thinness whose satirical wit is biting enough to endear, but carries holes in believability, while simplifying a character study that is simple enough in concept. There's a considerable charm to this film's simplicity, maybe even some, as Rotten Tomatoes' consensus puts it, elegance, but the fact of the matter is that this story is so simple, with limitations in potential that are stressed by the slow spells, familiarity and characterization thinness which would drive a lesser film into underwhelmingness. The strengths' being so subtle reflects a realization that endears consistently and thoroughly, until the film stands as yet another rewarding testament to Payne's skills as a minimal filmmaker, yet as with Payne's other projects, there's not much to make the final product all that strong, although there are plenty of questionable and familiar trademarks to Payne's storytelling that threaten to make this a relative misfire for the respectable filmmaker. In the end, however, Payne still manages to press the film on, maybe not where it stands out, even as much as some of Payne's earlier relative triumphs, but certainly to where you end up with a drama which even subtly endears stylistically.

Perhaps the most elegantly simplified aspect of this film is the black-and-white visual style, which is certainly lacking in liveliness, but about as hauntingly well-defined as the impeccably tight framing, fitting and adding to this tastefully minimalist drama so sharply that it immerses. Sure, most every immersive aspect to this naturalist opus sees great challenges within questionable storytelling aspects, but subtlety to recurring Alexander Payne collaborator Phedon Papamichael's cinematography, like most every other strength in this film, goes a long way in endearing as aesthetically appealing, as well as supplementary to the selling of minimalist engagement value that Alexander Payne drives, at least as director. Payne's trademark dryly thoughtful approach to intentionally limp subject matter is bland enough in its being so formulaic, and the many lapses in material momentum for Payne to meditate upon don't make matters any more gripping, but the film is far from dull, as Payne is once again able to get a fair degree of consistent entertainment value, punctuated by tenderly engaging dramatic licks. Payne's direction gets to be a little too subtle for its own good, but like I said, all of the subtle grace to Payne's direction goes a long way, because it's realized without getting pretentious, being simply comfortably thoughtful script that secures the final product from underwhelmingness because of its own subtle strengths. Bob Nelson's script is aimlessly draggy, formulaic and questionable developed, having questionable intentional flaws that do some damage to engagement value, yet are more-or-less compensated for by sharp dialogue and satirical, if thin characterization crafts memorable, maybe even overly familiar characters whose portrayers bring them to life. Granted, the onscreen performances aren't too much less subtle than the offscreen ones, but they endear just as thoroughly with their own subtle charm, and that particularly goes for the leads, with June Squibb and Will Forte being convincing as the struggling wife of a mentally distant senior, and as the caring, but personally flawed son of the same mentally distant senior, respectively, while Bruce Dern all but steals the show as the mentally distant senior himself, nailing the vacant charisma and very, very subtle layers that sell the confusion and price within the Woody Grant character. Yeah, it's all subtle this and subtle that, so, just like Payne's other films, this effort just isn't for everyone, but those willing to enter Payne's world yet again are sure to be endeared by the assurance, on and off of the screen, that make the final product rewarding.

At the end of the road, through all of the aimless dry and draggy spells and bland familiarity and simplicity, subtlety and grace to handsome visual style, thoughtful direction, clever writing and charismatic performance ultimately make Alexander Payne's "Nebraska" a comfortably realized and rewarding naturalist road dramedy.

3/5 - Good

A fairly minor film for Alexander Payne, Nebraska's riches lie in the interplay between its father-and-son co-leads rather than in its portrait of the Midwest. Bruce Dern pulls no punches as an aging man with borderline dementia and not-so-borderline alcoholism and Will Forte uses his deadpan SNL skills for a more serious note, but the rest of the characters fail to come to life (even if occasionally hilarious). As a low-key find, Nebraska is a fine movie, but perhaps the Oscar pedigree will hurt expectations.

Bruce Dern's performance in "Nebraska" as the senile Woody Grant did nothing for me. In fact the film may be my least favorite from director Alexander Payne. Essentially a father-and-son road trip to collect a lucky draw winning, the real plot rolled in 40 minutes later when Woody's news becoming a millionaire went public during his hometown stopover. But here Payne's usual witty sparks were diluted by Bob Nelson's somewhat push-to-move comedy about memories and grudges. The black/white canvas only upped its contrasts (and laughs) with June Squibb stealing every scene as the prickly but alert wife. "Nebraska" is of human pragmatism and filial piety, however in an unsatisfying and passive fit.

It was a fun, charming movie (that had me cracking up) but I honestly don't think it was Oscar-material. I really enjoyed it, but I think it was just missing that depth usually seen in most nominated films. Or maybe the execution was just off. Still, it was a great movie.

Dallas Buyer's Club was amazing and moving, American Hustle was slick and cool, 12 Years a Slave captivating and eye opening, Her was culturally relevant, Inside LLewyn Davis is the Coen Brothers nuff said, Philomena was heart warming, but Nebraska is the best of the bunch. Amazing acting, succinct but poignant dialogue, panoramic cinematography, a powerfully cathartic story about family and especially fathers and sons. A movie doesn't have to big or bold to be powerful, sometimes genius lies in doing simple really well. That's Nebraska.
Really good...great finish, even if it is sentimental...
Bruce Dern at his career best.  A sweet story with a timely message about keeping the dream alive.  I loved this movie!!
Yet another really nice film from Payne. Fern puts in an amazing performance in this heartbreaking, funny and beautiful film.

"I ain't fiddlin' with no cow titties. I'm a city girl!"

Alexander Payne has directed yet another powerful film by creating real characters going through real life situations in a very poignant and hilarious way. Nebraska is one of those films that manages to balance serious subject matters with light touches of comedy by creating characters from Midwestern American society that feel authentic and are easy to relate to. It's a heartwarming film with some very emotional dramatic moments that are taken to another level thanks to some strong performances. Bruce Dern stars in the role of a lifetime and his performance is so natural that he completely owns this movie and never misses a note. It's a difficult performance because due to the subject matter one wrong note could've made the audience feel like it was being manipulated, but it never does and Payne manages to direct his actors in such a way that I never felt he was being condescending. Will Forte also delivers in a strong dramatic role sharing great chemistry with Dern and making this a strong father-son road trip story that stands out above other such films. June Squibb is hilarious as well and she brings some comedic relief during some of the emotional or more dramatic moments. This road trip film is gorgeously captured through black and white cinematography giving the film a more nostalgic tone towards the past. It's a well balanced road film about old age and family, and one of Payne's best films (I'd rate it second, behind Sideways my personal favorite of his). This sad and tender film takes us through a journey that may be slow at times, but Payne makes sure he rewards his audience for sticking with it.

Written by Bob Nelson, Nebraska is an original screenplay centering on a Midwestern American family from Billings, Montana. The father, Woody Grant (Bruce Dern) who's in his late 70's and approaching dementia, is convinced that he has won a million dollars after receiving a newsletter, but everyone else in his family knows it's just one of those scams for people to purchase magazine subscriptions. His wife Kate (June Squibb) can't convince him otherwise and neither can their two adult sons, Ross (Bob Odenkirk) and David (Will Forte). Since no one will take him to Lincoln, Nebraska to collect his million dollars he tries to walk there. Finally David decides to call in sick at the electronic store where he works at and take his father to Lincoln. He believes this is a good opportunity to get closer to his estranged father who has always had alcohol related problems and been a very quiet person. Together they embark on the journey, but along the way they agree to stop by the small town in central Nebraska where his father grew up and meet up with their relatives. The trip becomes an illuminating experience for David who begins to understand some of the things that made his father the way he is, and through this unexpected journey the two grow closer together.

This could've been yet another forgettable father and son film, but thanks to Payne's unique style and deadpan humor along with Dern and Forte's powerful performances Nebraska is a beautiful and touching film. The tone of the film balances really well the family dynamics with the longing and yearning for the past mixed with the discomfort and emptiness of the present. Dern portrays this character so well and the final scenes he shares with Forte are touching and tender. It's a genuine story and in my opinion it's an improvement from Payne's previous film, The Descendants, which I enjoyed a little less than this one. Nebraksa is a very revealing film and I loved the way the father son relationship was slowly built without ever being manipulative.

In a few words, outside of the main actors, the acting was horrible, and the the movie incredibly boring!  Should have left in the middle, but thought something interesting might happen!
"No, he just believes what people tell him"

Nebraska is a road movie that morphs into an insightful comedy drama about family relationships. Bruce Dern (Woody) is exceptional as the cantankerous old father on the brink of senility who exasperates his wife and sons with his determination to collect a $1 million dollar prize that is so obviously a scam. As you'd expect, the journey turns out to be more important than the destination and although at times there seems to be a streak of misanthropy running through Nebraska, the way in which Woody's son discovers intriguing details about his father's past makes for an unexpectedly endearing story.

Initially I was perplexed as to why it was nominated for Best Picture, and I still am for Best Director, but the last half an hour was so touching and relatable, it made the whole picture very memorable.
Perfectly paced & highly quirky.

A road trip story about a grumpy old man bent on claiming a million dollars from a magazine sweepstakes turns out to be a very tender redemption tale of a father claiming his self-worth after decades of amounting to nothing.
Terrific movie that is equal parts humorous, sad and touching.

I personally don't think Alexander Payne has made a TRULY great film since "Election". He's made very good films, just not QUITE great. This continues his streak. But it's still a very, very good film. This is thanks to a trio of great performances. Bruce Dern is of course terrific as the elderly man who wants to go to Nebraska to claim the million dollars he believes he's won from a magazine. Will Forte shows that he's more than just "MacGruber" giving us a taste of what he's capable. But for me, it's June Squibb who steals the show. She just livens up the film every time she shows up. I have to say that the film toes a fine line between celebrating the idiosyncracies of American Midwestern people and just making fun of them. That said, there's still plenty to admire about in this film.
My new favorite 2013 film.
I think the choice to shoot this movie in black/white was so perfect. Dysfunctional as it seems at first, the love this family has for each other is so beautiful.

This young man, Davey really understand the meaning behind Dementia, it was a upfront approach to understanding the Disease, It is very heart touching story that I highly recommend to someone that has lost a love one before they actually did lose them, Sad but true! Loved it!!
Nebraska is a rare delight of a film that harks back to a golden era of American cinema.
not a typical "road trip" movie. Nebraska has very realistic acting and Bruce Dern & Will Forte put up great performances. Nebraska is simple yet very elegant, but also poetic and meaningful.

What a fantastic film. After seeing Robocop which had left a very bad taste in my mouth, Nebraska for sure cleaned up that mess. This is a heartwarming story of an ageing man who makes a trip from Montana to Nebraska with his estranged son in order to claim a million-dollar Mega Sweepstakes Marketing prize. The script is beautiful giving its characters such depth. Bruce Dern is absolutely fantastic in the leading role, definitely Oscar worthy. It's brilliantly shot by Phedon Papamichael who really gives it right feel for the story of the film. I can't actually find anything wrong with it. A+

This film takes its time, but all the better for it to gather power in the spare eloquence of its stunning, widescreen black and white imagery.  Payne's quietly confident orchestration of every artist involved (each contributing at the top of their game) brings palpable passion to what is easily his best work yet.  Dern and Forte lead an intricately assembled ensemble, each offering up nuanced moments of breathtaking intimacy that collectively left my jaw on the floor.

My Consensus:

Nebraska will become an iconic black and white film thanks to June Squibb's Oscar Take Home performance and amazing cinematography.

95/100 A

A funny and touching story about an old man who believes in everything people tell him. In this long journey in which he thinks he will become a millionaire after receiving a letter from a magazine, we learn about family, respect and, above all, love. Bruce Dern gives us a stunning performance and makes us fall in love with his innocent but determined and lovely character. June Squibb gives life to his sincere and smart wife, one of the best things in the script, while Will Forte plays his bored but good son. Beautiful film when it also comes to cinematography, with black and white instead of a coloured picture. This style suited well Nebraska's scenary, characters and story.

This family drama road film starring Bruce Dern, Will Forte and June Squibb, was one of the warmest film I've ever seen.  The director Alexander Payne and the writer Bob Nelson managed to make a film full with love even when the scenes and dialogue were completely opposite of how love is usually presented! And all that was possible only through the team work and the amazing acting abilities of most of the actors involved. There is no wonder that was nominated for the Palme d'Or at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival, and Bruce Dern's Best Actor Award at the same festival was well deserved. If anyone out there was wondering why this movie has been also nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director for Payne, Best Actor for Dern, Best Supporting Actress for Squibb, and Best Original Screenplay, please, watch it! You won't be wondering anymore...

The story of Woody Grant (Bruce Dern) and his son, David (Will Forte), who is taking his father to Lincoln, Nebraska to collect a $1 million sweepstakes prize he has won was somehow out of this world... but so familiar! The craziness of taking his father on a trip when David already knew that the sweepstakes letter is a mail scam to make a person purchase magazine subscriptions seemed quite normal (of course there are few more elements to this story, like David's mother Kate portrayed by June Squibb who will make everything more realistic).  I love Payne's 'Sideways', but this one was completely different road film. When he saw this screenplay he asked to direct it himself but didn't want to follow-up one road trip movie (he was in already in pre-production of Sideways), with another. He decided to wait until after completing The Descendants to pick up this project. This was the first film of Payne's in which he was not directly involved in the screenwriting, and he rewrote only a few things prior to the beginning of filming. And if you want to see the screenwriter Bob Nelson - he appears as an extra in a restaurant scene.

The film was shot in black and white because Payne said he wanted to produce an "iconic, archetypal look", and at the same time he perfectly used the poetic power of the black and white in combination with the wonderful landscapes. I would like to mention that the choice of black and white was made against distributor Paramount Vantage's wishes, and there is a colour version  created in an effort to satisfy distributor's concerns. Payne stated that he hopes no one ever sees it.

Like a cherry on top of this tasty film cake, there was the music composed by Tin Hat member Mark Orton. What a treat! 

Go ahead, and watch it as soon as possible if you like a good movie with nothing lacking!

A reminder that our views of our family are not always the whole picture. As a man endures a road trip with his father, he begins to see the other facets of his personality. In the end, he is better able to empathize, and learns that his dad is not such a bad guy.

A very special movie. I would expect nothing less from Alexander Payne.  I love his ability to make the harsh realities of life entertaining instead of depressing while still giving you warm fuzzies about it. And in a believable way. He's great. This movie was touching and never had to try too hard or go over the top, even though June Squib's character sure did! Great performance! The way the movie ended was perfect. It ended exactly where it needed to. I really appreciate when a movie doesn't need to draw everything out and put an exclamation point on their movie to let you know it's over. Very nice. Not sure I like it better than The Descendants, but I still really enjoyed and appreciated this.
A great cast and director helped make this an enjoyable film that's just the right blend of comedy, drama, and quirkiness. Give this one a watch. You'll be glad you did.

A marvelously vivid representation of middle American, blue collar life that simultaneously speaks to the power of family in each of our lives (even those of us that see no value in a new pick-up truck or air compressor). Truly beautiful stuff.

A touching road/father-son relationship movie. Very artistic, a bit slow at times, with more focus on the characters than the narrative - although there is a simple narrative. Filmed entirely in black and white I found the most stunning aspect the landscape shots. Acting is pretty good - particularly on the part of Bruce Dern who plays Woody Grant, the ageing, boozy, bordering-on-demented father who wants to travel to Lincoln, Nebraska to collect his $1m "prize" which is actually just a marketing ploy. It's a very gentle piece of cinema and mesmerising in a way. Maybe worth waiting for DVD unless you want to see the black and white photography on the big screen.

A photography exhibition, a great performance of the protagonist, an american pastoral sung by a chorus masterly directed by Payne. This is not only an american movie indeed, its plot is universal and it's where I'd like to spend two words about. 
The theory of the frontier moves Woody to travel, he may represent the old agricultural sector moving towards future to the automotive production. Following the economic crisis even Woody is lost and his friends are too. His son caresses the dreams of his father, gets astonished even watching the Rushmore monument, believes in technology and in the future. He'll move across a path of evolution and self adfirmation until there will not be any regard for his efforts than his on inteligence and spirit of resilience. 
This movies shows the feeelings and the purpose of our generation (30 y.o.) at his best.
This was my favourite  movie of the year! It had a great message, all the acting was excellent and I smiled all the way through! Enjoyed every second! Go see it, highly recommended
Fantastic movie in so many ways.  One that I will watch again and again.

Another Alexander Payne classic. Bruce Dern is always great, but Will Forte (no relation) was surprisingly strong and June Squibb walks away with every scene she is in (she is my personal pick for the Best Supporting Actress nom).
Simple, sweet, funny.
Check out my review here: http://www.haplessgeek.com/2014/02/critiqued-nebraska.html

Nebraska is one of the strongest Oscar contenders of the year. Its story is small, but it shows something few movies do - what it truly feels like being old and living in a very small place. The acting is very good and the pacing is excellent, the story is well-crafted, emotionally conveyed, incredibly realistic and relevant plus the message is deep and poignant. Nebraska is honestly one of the finest dramas of 2013.

Spoiler Alert:
If only David would have bought his father the bloody truck and compressor to begin with, we could all have been spared 115 minutes of our lives watching nothing aimless going nowhere. Pity because I had grown fond of Alexander Payne's work as of late.

I loved Bruce Dern in the Cowboys!!! He is such a great actor. He was a bad guy in the Cowboys but a good old man in this flick. This movie was in black and white and I thought that was a perfect idea. Go see it.
There's a point early on where you forget you're just an observer and start feeling like part of the Grant family. It's definitely a ride you want to take.

Nebraska is a fundamental story of love and simple desires, neither of which are fully exposed or realized until the end, a perfect ending that explores true joy and satisfaction and how they may be embraced and experienced in the most unexpected of ways. It's also a story about faith, not in money but in people, and particularly family. Whether there's a million dollars at the end of the rainbow or just an "aw, shucks, no money but here's a cheap Chinese-made consolation prize" is of no matter; it's family, it's love, it's understanding that make the journey to whatever may lie at the end worth the sacrifices. This is a remarkable film, easily deserving of its Oscar nominations, and a good bet to have a big night on March 2.
Good movie but is not a masterpiece. Had some moments, good actors and good director.
This was a great movie.  Bruce Dern plays a grand part.  ? and white truly did add to the timing and

"When your father got old, you should be his father!". One sentence? "I really admire life lessons shown simply and honestly by Alexander Payne". 

This is another road movie that you touch its simplicity and enjoy it until the last moment. It's not a story of winning million dollar, it's the million dollar story to tell us how responsible about our aged parents we should be. "Woody Grant" (Bruce Dern) is one of us, a father with a lot of unachieved hopes trying to prove himself as alive even in his hangovers. He is beer addict, fanciful, but extremely simple-hearted and generous. "David" (Will Forte) also one of us, a son with his own life who refuses to put his father in a nursing home and tries kindly to make his father's dream down. Well, did he really believe he is about to become a lottery millionaire, or he intently ignoring the truth? Who cares about the money here? I guess I really fell in love with my parents again after it!

With no frills, Alexander Payne's Nebraska comes as a warm lovable black comedy painted in black and white with great cinematography, which never goes far away of Payne's long shots heavily detailed slow developed pictures. Yeah, it's about old-aged parents, with a lot of youth secrets of them revealed suddenly to the ears of their kids, and superb chemistry all over this family. Old joyful secrets in a tough time. Bruce Dern back to Oscar consideration after 25 years in his naïve touching performance, with strong-languaged June Squib twinkling as a woman wants to keep her family, and a warm screenplay by Bob Nelson, though I felt nothing original in it. 

Nebraska takes me back to the golden era of cinema, and proves me again that modest stories are the best.
Great performances all around, especially by Dern and Squibb.

Nebraska is a well made depressing film about an alcoholic elder not feeling ready to just settle for death to come get him and the infinite love of one of his sons who decides to carry on with his delusional fantasy once he concludes that no one can make his father understand that words - even written ones- have no value whatsoever, nowadays.

The movie also explores how much simpler and unspoken things were among couples, fifty plus years ago.  No questions asked, no moods explained, no futures discussed, no romantic nonsense, no major decisions to be made.  Things just happened.  Marrying was the only approved way to have sex, so marriage it was!  Kids were the logical consequence of having sex.  Work was the only way to support it all.  Life itself was a matter of being lucky... or not!  Some made it, some simply died.  Just like that.  Life had nothing much more to offer other than knowing what was going on in everybody's' lives and the occasional gathering with your awkward family to watch a football game.  No one stood up in that town nor made it big, so gossip and delusions were easy to buy, got cheered on and would definitely awaken all sorts of responses on these otherwise uneventful townsmen.
This film grabs you at the beginning and holds your attention till the end despite, at times, a slower pace. Witty, funny, relatable, heartwarming, this movie is a breath of fresh air.

Much funnier than I was expecting. Bruce Dern is getting a lot of praise for his role, but I thought he was better overall in his role on Big Love; at least here he's not playing a bastard. Some great black and white photography on display here as well.

This is one film where I think the decision to film in black and white was a good one. It gives the film a tired atmosphere which fits to the story very well. It's a great film with some very funny moments. The oscar nominations are a surpise for me but I expect it to win something.
it's unique movie. This movie also has great shot and great design. Quite funny, old-man-funny type, and it has enjoyable view even though  its black-and-white movie.
A slow start gradually turns into a fantastic ending. Loads of heart here.

It's deep into the Oscar season and I've begun my mad dash to get all of the Best Picture nominees watched before the big ceremony on March 2nd. Having seen Philomena, Captain Phillips, American Hustle and Dallas Buyers Club already, I next turned my attention to Alexander Payne's road trip dramedy "Nebraska", a pleasant little homage to family relationships and a sincere look at American existence.

One of the most interesting things about "Nebraska" is the cinematography. I'm not referring to the black-and-white the film is shot in, necessarily, either; Payne creates a sense of melancholy using wide shots of vast wildernesses and giving a sense of intimate grandeur to the small towns the Grants visit. The roadtrip "Nebraska" centers on is made to be a kind of synecdoche for American life as a whole, and contains many sentimental scenes where characters reflect on past experiences, victories and defeats, losses and failures, and seem to pass them off as "that's the way it is". Payne takes Bob Nelson's wonderful screenplay and lets its characters almost reflect on themselves; the acting is so natural the direction would be unnoticeable if the cinematography wasn't so good.

The film stars Bruce Dern as Woody Grant, a stubborn, near-senile old man who is excited to find a letter in his mail proclaiming that he could win a million dollars if he travels to Lincoln, Nebraska to claim his prize. His wife, Kate (June Squibb, in one of the most hilarious supporting performances in recent memory) and oldest son Ross (Bob Odenkirk, as awesome here as he was in Breaking Bad) dismiss his claims and tell him that it's a scam (it clearly is) and he should let it go, but his more sympathetic younger son, David (Will Forte on top subtlety form) tries to convince the other two that this may be the last opportunity at excitement Woody may ever have, and decides to drop his job (he sells TVs) for a few days and take his dad (against the wishes of the rest of his family) down to Nebraska.

On the way down to Nebraska, Woody gets into an accident and they are forced to stop in Woody's old hometown of Hawthorne, where Woody is basically forced against his will to visit old family members and friends, more than a few of whom he seems to owe something to. When Woody proudly tells everyone that he's soon to be a millionaire, the major conflict of the movie begins and what follows is a turbulent, sad, and powerful look at the selfishness and apathy of rural Americans and people in general. Whether or not Nelson and Payne's intent was to be satirical or sincere, the film is an excellent character study, with Ed Pegram (Stacy Keach) providing one of the scariest human villains in a realistic drama for quite some time.

As Woody, Bruce Dern lives and exists as a character that doesn't seem to be acted in any way, proof of his masterful performance. Of the actors I've so far seen, he is probably the most deserving of the Best Actor Oscar (not to put down McConaughey, who will quite rightly win, and Christian Bale, who made American Hustle; I have not seen 12 Years a Slave or The Wolf of Wall Street Yet). His embodiment is at times hilarious, inspiring, pathetic, realistic, beautiful, artistic, and revealing. His relationship with his son David was for me the highlight of the movie, an honest depiction of a tumultuous but altogether loving connection that survives even in the hardest of times.

I think at heart "Nebraska" is a comedy, because it doesn't lament on its lead characters flaws and ends in a happy (and surprising) way. There are horrible torments in between, but they are offset by multiple laugh-out-loud moments and some truly touching scenes. My favorite scene involves David and Ross stealing a compressor from a barn because they thought it was rightfully Woody's. What follows is absolutely hilarious.

The dialogue is a revelation, enough to make Bob Nelson deserving of an Original Screenplay Oscar if "Her" wasn't a thing. Squibb's dialogue is my favorite, and combined with some side-splitting moments with her in the film, makes her the best supporting actress I've so far seen this year.

As a whole, "Nebraska" is a masterpiece of writing, directing, acting, and celebrating life in general. Go see it and you will not be disappointed. It's the best American human drama since "The Descendants".
Me being from the Midwest, Nebraska really hit close to home. Instant classic!

Still a good actor
A different story
Just to slow
Quirky and unforgettable.   Bruce Dern and his wife are unforgettable.   Slow and sometimes bleak,  but a nice pay off when you get to the end.
this is a great journey. the actors do a great job.
Great screenplay that combines drama and comedy perfectly
Interesting little film. Will Forte does a really good. Bruce Dern is great. I like how it was shot in black-and-white. Just a funny little comedy.
good, but simple plot. great view on everything but yeah.

A wonderful portrait of a father/son relationship in which something akin to Alzheimers acts as the catalyst for a family reunion. This film walks a fine line between sadness and comedy with some wonderfully poignant moments. The cast are superb in this, especially Bruce Dern as the dithering father and June Squibb as his long-suffering wife.

This movie did manage to capture the look and feel of small town America.  That said, it's way too slow and boring.  It moves at a snail's pace and nothing is really happening for like 90 percent of the time.  The movie doesn't really seem to have much of a point besides giving an old man one last thrill, one last walk down memory lane, and one last ride of glory.  The dialog was mostly flat and pedestrian (obviously not written by Alexander Payne, whose scripts usually have excellent dialog) and all of the actors' delivery were weirdly overacted, like a bunch of amateurs putting an unrealistic amount of inflection into their lines. (It's hard for me to describe it in words at the moment, but a good example can be seen with the doctor in Black Dynamite: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3uUDMR_-tUk&t=30) Most of the characters were annoying and I didn't connect to a single one of them, aside from some brief moments of gratitude for Kate for telling things straight and shutting dumbasses up.

Bruce Dern was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor for this?  He did fine, but his performance wasn't extraordinary, given what little he had to work with; I mean, half of his lines were "WHAT?!"  This Oscar slot would've been better off going to Joaquin Phoenix for Her.  I could say the same for June Squibb, who had some memorable lines but delivered them with the same weird fake exaggerated singsong style that was characteristic of this movie's acting.  Her Supporting Actress Oscar nomination should've gone to Léa Seydoux for Blue is the Warmest Color.  Hell, Nebraska's nomination for Best Picture should've gone to Blue is the Warmest Color.

The black and white aspect didn't do anything for me, but the storyline was good, and Bruce Dern and June Squibb gave excellent performances.

There comes a time in life when you are not yourself anymore. True depiction of old age problems through a well written and well directed script. Great portrayal of an old man losing his memory by Bruce Dern. 4 out of 5.

Happy and sadly about the American Dream, Nebraska is a brilliant masterpiece, magnificently directed by Alexander Payne. Bruce Dern delivers a heart warming performance as an aging alcoholic in pursuit of his million dollar prize, when in reality, his pipe dream is full of longing and a regretful life. Shot in black & white, Nebraska's cinematography is handsome and a stunning treat for the eyes. I give this bittersweet tale of family 4 1/2 stars out of 5. Loved this movie.

Alexander Payne is a director who never forgot where he came from. I mean, why else would he shoot most of his movies in the state of Nebraska. He likes to make flicks about real people. He also likes to make flicks about people who look like real people, act like real people, and live in boring, realistic places. He does all of this while being totally beloved by the Academy. He's been nominated three times for best director (a list that includes the film I'm reviewing) and doesn't go for the jugular. He doesn't need special effects, shock value, gaudy camerawork, or beautiful Hollywood types to get his point across. No Payne is a good ol' fashioned filmmaker and with Nebraska, he provides another good ol' fashioned film going experience. With this November of 2013 release, he shoots everything in black and white. I'm not exactly sure why he does it nor do I wanna know the reason (I want it to be a mystery). But it doesn't matter though because frankly, it just works.

Also, as with his other triumphant trysts in the world of cinema (Sideways and About Schmidt being my personal favorites next to this one), Nebraska is yet another road trip movie. And I believe that Payne thinks of this as his comfort zone when it comes to fortifying his vision. In truth, I'm 100% on board with said vision.

Penned by a first time screenwriter (Bob Nelson) and featuring characters who's lives are non-enriched, bleak, and not entirely promising (the black and white hue I feel, echos a lot of this), Nebraska tells the tale of Billings, Montana resident Woody Grant (Bruce Dern). He's I guess a retired mechanic, an on-again, off- again alcoholic, and a distant father to his two sons (David Grant played by Will Forte and Ross Grant played by Bob Odenkirk). When he finds out that he might have won a million dollars (through a letter that might be a scam), he then is bent on going to Lincoln, Nebraska to pick up his so-called winnings. Since his wife (played by June Squibb) won't drive him to Lincoln, he aids the help of his youngest son to get him there (Woody is forbidden to drive and it would take forever to walk 700 plus miles). As a road trip ensues, the rest of the Grant family eventually meets up (the older brother and mother take a bus instead) and rekindles their family history with their other relatives who live in the small town of Hawthorne, Nebraska. When these other relatives (certain people who are not part of the immediate family) find out that Woody is about to become rich, they want a piece of his winnings because well, he owes them some sort of prolonged debt.

Now as much as I liked the middle America vibe I got from Nebraska, I couldn't quite render it a four star rating. The film's only oversight might be a few scenes that drag and a couple of scenes that mainly just feel like filler. The scenes that drag almost bring the two hour running time to a screeching halt. The scenes that act as filler are examples like Woody and his brothers watching football games and hardly saying a word to each other. I could do without the irreverence of those tidbits. But honestly, this flick as a whole doesn't really suffer from what I just mentioned. The audience with a keen sense of patience, will embrace what's on screen anyway.

The cast of Nebraska, (which consists of knowns and unknowns), comes up aces all around. Bruce Dern plays Grant with a low key stubbornness. He does a lot of reacting and doesn't go over the top. His performance as a comatose senior citizen, is Oscar worthy because at 77 years old, it doesn't even feel like he's acting. His style is so unassuming and it is so in the moment. To be honest, I haven't seen much of Dern's work but I know that he's been in the AEA union since the early sixties. That's gotta say something. Will Forte, who usually goes for the funny and plays goofballs (like in the little seen McGruber and some SNL stuff), is something of a revelation here. His David Grant is sort of a long lost daddy's boy who sees this road trip as a way to spend more time with his dad, and get to know more about what makes him tick. Forte, who matches Dern scene for scene, plays it serious with a level of disciplined perception. I don't know much about him or the facets of his career, but I do know that he is almost perfect for the role (my only stipulation is that he might have looked to young to play Squibb and Dern's character's son). As for June Squibb, she gives the best performance out of everybody. She comes on like a firecracker as Woody's nagging wife who still has his best interests at heart. Every scene she is in is a stealer. Her two best moments are visiting the family's graveyard in Hawthorne and telling off other members of the family who go after Woody hoping to get a piece of him financially.  Squibb just recently got nominated for best supporting actress in this role. I don't know if she'll win but I'm definitely pulling for her.

Flawless acting stints aside, as you watch Nebraska, you figure out more and more that this is not a film about Woody getting his jackpot of a million dollars. What you see is the journey of the Grant clan sort of finding themselves. And the centralized part of that journey involves the vein of the father/son dynamic. The small town of Hawthorne, Nebraska provides the Grants with insight into their family roots, where they grew up, and their friends who seem to all know them from long ago. The character development safe to say, is exceptional here because we get a back story on pretty much everybody. Basically, all the players in Nebraska's setting look and act like your normal everyday Joes. No one and I mean no one who appears on screen, is underdeveloped or for a better word, unrealized. 

All and all, the one thing I enjoyed most about this critical darling, is the ending. This ending, which puts a band aid on everything that's happened before it, will leave feeling lumpy and agog. In a sense, Nebraska has pitch perfect performances and direction that is careful and resounding. This to my liking, makes it a personable film with a giant heart. The movie poster which looks like Bob Dylan's Greatest Hits album cover, would persuade anyone to view this thing being that it has that old-world feel to it. And although the proceedings are slow at times giving the evocation of watching paint dry, it's a good kind of paint. Overall, Nebraska is another notch in the belt of Payne's heartfelt Nebraskan roots. Out of the 100 plus films that surfaced in 2013, this one is truly a keeper.

Understated to a fault.  This movie made me want to kill myself.  The bleakness was overdone; the actors were wooden.  I don't understand the Oscar buzz for this movie.  Stacy Keach delivered the best performance of the cast.  Everyone else read cue cards after being given heavy doses of Xanax.  The underlying story in interesting, but the execution is overwrought and condescending.  Also, the casting perplexes me.  Will Forte seems far too young to have a doddering father, which I'm surprised has not been mentioned by others.  The elderly mother was over-the-top crude (which was considered charming by some???  I don't get it.).  Meh.  Depressing and flat.  I was excited to see something that was refreshingly non-Hollywood.  Well, this wasn't "Hollywood," but it surely was flat and colorless.

Alexander Payne's Nebraska gets truly touching by the end, and depending on the kind of person you are prior to this movie can be either a tragedy or a comedy. While there's definitely some pity thrown out at once, I did consider this a funny movie. The crude dialogue was right up my style, and Alexander Payne capitalizes on his wit through the no bull sh*t June Squibb. I fell in love with the whole cast, Bruce Dern (who really deserves the best actor), Will Forte (in a plain but clear role), Bob Odenkirk (better call Saul), but most importantly June Squibb. Nebraska succeeds in painting the small town life, in which most never get out of. With themes of alcoholism and delusion coming from Bruce Dern, it's hard not to feel any empathy for the character, but at the same time I laughed out loud several times.

Alexander Payne has a great track record and NEBRASKA is thankfully no exception to the rule. Anther smart movie in his cap.  Even my least favourite of his films, THE DESCENDANTS had a certain beauty to it.  Payne's eccentric take on everyday stories of everyday people are quiet yet powerful studies on the human condition.  Once again, he's managed to bring beauty to the simplicity of life's uglier side.  NEBRASKA is both insightful and thoughtful.  Stunningly shot in black & white, Payne, once again, wrings out natural performance from his entire cast.  As always in his films, there's a keen eye for authentic casting true to the mood and atmosphere of the story but  even more so to the setting of the film, in this case the rural Northwest.  And to top it all off, Bruce Dern does deserve every single accolade he's so far received.

Damn near perfect movie.  Possibly the best story on screen within the last year.  How does a picture this great only make $15m??  Anyway...this is one of my favorite movies this great Oscar season...one of the best in many years.  It's funny and poetic and the filmography is wonderful to watch.  Definitely see this movie...if not in the theater, on DVD...on Feb 25th.
I think I have a new favorite movie. Comical and poignant, brilliantly cast. Highly recommend.

Alexander Payne has a knack for capturing the situations of men approaching a defining time in their  life with humor and plenty of emotion. "Nebraska" is another entry in a string of films in the 2000's that fit the theme I describe above. Bruce Dern, Will Forte, and June Squibb are dynamic together, and they light up the screen with chemistry and humor. Squibb in particular lit up every scene she was in (not that she had much work to do). The writing, like in most Payne films, is humorous. The screenplay also offers characters that we care about, they are interesting and have dimensions.  "Nebraska" is a very human movie, down-to-earth and very entertaining.

I really enjoyed this movie. It is a truly heartwarming tale and an insight into an elderly mans broken outlook on life. It's really quite a simple concept, but the movie is character driven and the development of their narratives is truly awe inspiring. I really loved the feel of the movie and I feel the black and white added a special element which may not have been there if it were in colour. I think it was added to represent how the gentleman sees the world, in black and white with no grey areas. Such a beautiful movie, really enjoyable from beginning to end.

The last of the 2014 Best Picture Nominees that I had to watch and whilst I did like it, I thought other movies (The Butler, Rush) were more worthy of the spot. I like how it was shot in Black & White which brought attention to the characters and not the scenery, as I'm sure the landscape was beautiful. The trailer showed a lot of "laugh out loud" moments from June Squibb but when watching the movie I thought her crass remarks were forced and she a bit of a skank. A sweet ending.
4.5/5  Loved it.  The half star is because of the black and white.  I felt it took away from the movie instead of whatever it was supposed to do.
